text: Arcade Fire the suburbs hi my needle
drops kit can I assume you know who
these guys are
can I assume that uh we're gonna do an
album review yeah
Arcade Fire is a Canadian band who
arguably is one of the top poster
children for modern indie and I
understand whether this album is good or
bad or whether Arcade Fire is good or
bad is all opinion but I think anybody
should be able to come away at least
appreciating their sound or seeing why
other people would like it
you've got wind Butler's dramatic vocals
you have the always ambitious production
instrumentation plus songs that are just
dying to wrestle with your emotions and
that's what made records like 2004's
funerals so freakin appealing Arcade
Fire built on that sound
in 2007 going in a direction that was
more orchestral and more thematic - and
I know a lot of people have preferred
funeral over Neon Bible but still I
think Bible is arguably a more cohesive
album is it a more enjoyable album I
don't know but does it have a more
overarching theme yes and now we're at
the suburbs which I feel has hit the
sweet spot that Arcade Fire's
previous efforts have missed in terms of
a media see this thing beats funeral to
the finish line and when it comes to
ambition and concept this thing closes
Neon Bible now there's going to be a lot
of which album is the best album kinda
talked surrounding this LP I don't
necessarily see the suburbs as better
but merely Arcade Fire trying to grab
the best elements of all of their
previous releases and just run with it
while still pursuing some sounds that
the band is kind of yet to try the very
first thing that struck me about the
suburbs is this is really Arcade Fire's
most concentrated attempt at producing
rock music just straightforward
straight-up unfettered
music a lot of tracks like month of May
city with no children and ready to start
art as flowery as a lot of Arcade Fire's
previous work aren't so much dressed to
impress
but our aiming for something a lot more
visceral shooting straight for the gut
but despite the straightforwardness of
this album the band has not forgotten
their orchestral roots has not forgotten
to sound huge sound big just make a
gigantic production of their music the
strings the keys the backup vocals are
sounding more complimentary than they
ever have meaning that the production
rarely overpowers the songs for the sake
of showing off there's some quieter
moments on this LP too and what I love
about these tracks is just Arcade Fire's
sense and appreciation of space and
atmosphere there's no struggle of space
and atmosphere there's no struggle to
hear an instrument stuff's not getting
drowned out everything has a place and
is arranged very precisely precise and
in terms of concept and just the theme
of these songs this album paints a
pretty depressing dark dreary picture of
suburbia claiming a place in the
rat-race imagery of falling houses of
fading past not a pretty picture
and if you guys are regular viewers of
the videos you know that I'm not a huge
lyrics person it's really one of the
last things that strikes me on the album
but as I listen to the suburbs over and
over I couldn't help but just hang on
almost every one of Wynn butler's words
just a lot of fantastic storytelling the
production the sound of these tracks is
extremely impressive and this LP was
co-produced with markus drives who's
also worked with Brian Eno Bjork
Coldplay
so the band is in pretty good hands here
but the production is really where my
only gripe about this album comes from
there are several tracks on here like
empty room or half light to where I feel
like
the instrumentation is just so
cacophonous it's almost as if every part
of it is just fighting to be heard
everything blaring at the same volume
and the result is sadly kind of a flat
sound it's nice every once in a while to
kind of create a wall of sound have a
swell but when these things kind of drag
on for the length of almost the entire
track it tends to sound as if it just
has a lack of dynamics of course there's
a lot of variation among these tracks
which is to be expected that's always
the case with Arcade Fire's music and
the most prominent element among all
these tracks is just the sound of what
we know as Americana I just hear a lot
of influence coming from these great
anthemic
80s rock songs from singer songwriters
like Tom Petty the boss Bruce
Springsteen there are quite a few spots
of New Wave on this album too with just
throbbing synthesizers that really keep
the pace going and can I just say the
track sprawl - sounds a lot like heart
of glass which is not a bad thing so if
you're looking for an hour-long pop and
rock record loaded with ambition
mournful lyrics cinematic production
along with the occasional fist pumping
rocker Arcade Fire's the suburbs let me
know what you think of this album are
you loving it are you hating it and you
know what I didn't even I never even
asked Cal what he thought about this LP
